title: Cateran Trail Walking Route

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The Cateran Trail, Bamff. The route now passes through the Bamff Estate to lessen the amount of road walking, a feature which the trail has been criticised for in the past.

images.title: Lis Burke / Lochan by the Cateran Trail
images.caption: Lochan by the Cateran Trail. Probably a fishing lochan, as a boathouse can be seen between the lichen-covered trees.

images.title: Rob Burke / Glen Isla from the Cateran Trail
images.caption: Glen Isla. On a grey December afternoon, a short spell of sunshine showed how the glen might be on a good day. The hill opposite is (I think) Creag Reamhar.

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: The 64 mile trail uses this farm road at Knockie to take walkers towards the Bridge of Cally.

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Above Blairgowrie. The red heart logo indicates the route of the Cateran Trail as it heads along the track towards the Bridge of Cally. Our route is left towards Maryfield.

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Sign for the Trail at Enochdhu. Enochdhu means 'black moor'. The trail takes its name from cattle rustlers(caterans) who the Middle Ages until the 17th century flourished in the region and made good use of remote hill passes such as this to quickly move herds of stolen cattle and other booty. Cateran raiding parties were feared, with good cause.

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Hill of Alyth. The Hill of Alyth comprises multiple summits, the highest of which rises to 300m (984 feet). The path is part of the Cateran Trail.

images.title: Trish Steel, CC BY-SA 2.0 <https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/2.0>, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cateran Trail near Alyth

description: Explore the Perthshire Glens on this circular walk through Kirkmichael, Enochdhu, Spittal of Glenshee, Cray and Alyth. There are lovely waterside sections along the River Ardle, Shee Water and Drumore Loch. The walk begins and ends at Blairgowrie and is waymarked with a heart logo on a white disc.
